Humans, Environment & Emotions

Good morning everyone. Is it sarcastic to say "good" morning to someone on a Monday morning?

Today I will spend 5 minutes talking about my shit (research shit).

I recently got very interested in the idea of mapping human behavior, and what sorts of things we could find out by doing so.

What would even be mapped really?

Could behavior even properly be mapped?

Well turns out, people's stress can be mapped to measure how people respond to the environment, but properly? well kinda

People are complex, and so is their behavior. Meaning we cant just rely on one data source to properly study it. And its even worse if we used traditional visalization methods. Here's what I mean.

  • Research Question: Do certain exhibits cause more excitement in museum visitors over others?
  • Goal: Compute Geospatial Emotion Model
  • Purpose: Assist museum directors to design most engaging museum possible

This brings us to our next project in Nuenen at the Vincent Van Gogh Musuem.

Visitors' location and emotional experiences were again collected while experiencing both inside and outside exhibits at the museum.

Who cares?

This brings us to our next project in Nuenen at the Vincent Van Gogh Musuem.

Visitors' location and emotional experiences were again collected while experiencing both inside and outside exhibits at the museum.

What sort of data is required in a "Geospatial Emotion Model"?

  • All data. To ever exist:
    • Person ID
    • Location (x,y)
    • Time (spent in location)
    • Skin Conductance
    • Direction (to & from exhibits)
    • Velocity
    • Distance to Exhibits
    • Viewshed (indoors & outdoors)
This brings us to our next project in Nuenen at the Vincent Van Gogh Musuem.

Visitors' location and emotional experiences were again collected while experiencing both inside and outside exhibits at the museum.
